docs.title: What is Steev?
docs.text:
Steev is an AI-powered training assistant that revolutionizes your AI training workflow:

✨ Zero Configuration Required ✨ Automated Management ✨ Enhanced Performance

Whether you’re working with LLMs, computer vision, or any deep learning models, Steev streamlines your workflow and maximizes productivity.

docs.title: 🤝 Review with Your Engineering Buddy
docs.text: Think of Steev as your always-available colleague. Through natural conversation, Steev helps you easily manage your training process.

docs.title: 🚀 24/7 Babysitter for Your Training
docs.text:
No more babysitting your training process. Steev provides intelligent guidance and support by:

  • Continuous monitoring the training process
  • Proactively detecting anomalies

docs.title: 📊 Real-Time Monitoring & Notifications
docs.text:
Keep track of what matters:

  • Model metrics (loss, accuracy)
  • Training progress
  • Convergence patterns

Instant alerts when your attention is needed - no more constant checking!

Run your training process with Steev and forget about it. Steev will take care of the rest.

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: This guide will help you install Steev on your system and get started quickly.

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.11 or higher
  • Packages required for your training code (e.g. transformers, unsloth)

Platform Support

Currently, Steev has been tested only on Linux systems. MacOS and Windows support is planned for future releases.

docs.title: Using pip (Recommended)
docs.text:
The easiest way to install Steev is using pip:

pip install steev

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
After installation, verify that Steev is installed correctly by running:

steev version

You should see output similar to: 

steev version 0.1.0

docs.title: Initial Setup
docs.text:
Before using Steev, you’ll need to authenticate. Run:

steev auth login

You’ll be presented with two authentication options:

  1. Browser Login (Recommended for local machines)

  2. Opens your default web browser for a seamless login experience

  3. Token Login (For remote servers)

  4. Uses an authentication token when browser access isn’t available
Choose authentication method:
  Log in with web browser (Login from local)
  Paste an auth token (Login from remote server)

Remote Server Usage

If you’re working on a remote server without browser access, choose the “Paste an auth token” option. You can generate an auth token from your account settings page.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you have Steev installed and configured:

  1. Follow our Quick Tour to learn the basics
  2. Explore the Command Reference for detailed usage
  3. Check out Tutorials for practical examples

Need Help?

If you run into any issues during installation, please join our community Discord.

docs.title: Quick Tour 🚀
docs.text: Welcome to Steev! This guide will help you get started with our AI-powered training assistant.

docs.title: Getting Started 🎯
docs.text:
After installing Steev, you can start using it with a simple command:

steev run train.py

Need to customize training parameters? No problem! Use the --kwargs flag:

steev run train.py --kwargs "learning-rate=0.001 batch-size=32"

💡 Pro tip: You can use shorthand arguments too: 

steev run train.py --kwargs "lr=0.001 bs=32"

docs.title: What Happens Next? 🔄
docs.text: When you run Steev, it springs into action with three main phases:

docs.title: 1. Code Review & Analysis 🔍
docs.text:
• ✅ Analyzes your training code
  • ✅ Reviews configurations and dependencies
  • ⬜️ Provides smart suggestions for improvements

docs.title: 2. Training Supervision 📊
docs.text:
• ✅ Monitors training metrics in real-time
  • ✅ Detects and alerts you about anomalies
  • ⬜️ Manages computational resources efficiently
  • ⬜️ Automatically adjusts parameters when needed

docs.title: 3. Optimization & Results 🎯
docs.text:
• ⬜️ Fine-tunes hyperparameters intelligently
  • ⬜️ Selects the best model weights
  • ⬜️ Generates comprehensive training reports
  • ⬜️ Provides insights for future improvements

docs.title: Next Steps 🌟
docs.text:
Ready to explore more? Here’s your roadmap:

Resource Description 💡 Tutorials Hands-on examples and guides 👥 Discord Community Join our active community 🔧 Commands Explore all available commands

Need help? Join our Discord community or check out our documentation.

docs.title: steev config file
docs.text: steev config file is a yaml file that contains the configuration for the analysis.

docs.title: 📚 Tutorials
docs.text: To Be Updated

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
Manage your authentication using the steev auth command.

steev auth <subcommand>

During the beta phase, Steev is completely free. However, authentication is required since the LLM Agent needs to analyze your logs to provide optimal service.

docs.title: login
docs.text:
Log in or sign up for your Steev account. You have two authentication methods available:

  1. Browser-based login (recommended for local machines)
  2. Token-based login (useful for remote servers)
steev auth login

When you run the login command, you’ll see: 

Choose authentication method:
> Log in with web browser (Login from local)
  Paste an auth token (Login from remote server)

Steev uses Google OAuth for authentication. After successful login, your credentials are stored in ~/.steev/credentials.json:

{
  "user": "username", 
  "email": "steev@steev.io", 
  "token": {
    "access_token": "your-access-token",
    "refresh_token": "your-refresh-token",
    "access_exp": 1738657951  // Expiration timestamp
  }
}

docs.title: status
docs.text:
Check your current authentication status:

steev auth status

Example output: 

Credential
  user   
  email  steev@steev.io
tokens
  access_token   your-access-token...
  refresh_token  your-refresh-token...
  access_exp     2099-12-25 23:59:59

docs.title: logout
docs.text:
Sign out and remove stored credentials:

steev auth logout

This command: - Revokes your access and refresh tokens - Deletes the ~/.steev/credentials.json file

You’ll see: 

Successfully logged out

docs.title: verify
docs.text:
Verify if your current credentials are valid:

steev auth verify

You’ll see one of these messages: 

Credential token is valid
or 
Credential token is invalid

docs.title: refresh
docs.text:
Manually refresh your authentication tokens:

steev auth refresh

This command: - Obtains new access and refresh tokens - Updates the ~/.steev/credentials.json file

You’ll see: 

Credential token refreshed

docs.title: Run Experiments
docs.text:
Execute your training code using the steev run command. Steev automatically runs your experiment code and analyzes the results, eliminating the need to write additional scripts.

Warning

The current version of Steev only supports the transformers and unsloth libraries.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text: steev run TRAIN_FILE [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Required Arguments
docs.text: • TRAIN_FILE: Path to your training script (e.g., train.py)

docs.title: Optional Arguments
docs.text:
• --steev-cfg PATH: Path to your Steev configuration file (default: steev.cfg)
  • --kwargs "KWARG1=VAL1,KWARG2=VAL2": Keyword arguments to pass to your training script

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Run a basic training script: 

steev run train.py

Specify a custom config file: 

steev run train.py --steev-cfg custom_steev.cfg

Pass training parameters: 

steev run train.py --kwargs "epoch=10 lr=0.001 batch_size=32"
# Or using commas
steev run train.py --kwargs epoch=10,lr=0.001,batch_size=32

docs.title: Passing Keyword Arguments
docs.text:
You can pass any keyword arguments to your training script using the --kwargs option. These work just like regular Python keyword arguments - no modifications to your training code required.

Formatting kwargs

There are two ways to format your kwargs:

  1. Using spaces (must be quoted): 

    steev run train.py --kwargs "epoch=10 lr=0.001"

  2. Using commas (no quotes needed): 

    steev run train.py --kwargs epoch=10,lr=0.001

docs.title: Experiment Monitoring
docs.text:
During training, Steev actively monitors your experiment logs for anomalies. If any issues are detected:

  1. You’ll receive an email notification
  2. The email will include an “Abort Experiment” button
  3. Clicking the button will safely stop your experiment
